PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD


    The Public Utilities Board is continuing to develop its production and distribution facilities to meet the steadily rising demand for electricity, water and gas. Capital development expenditure for 1977 was $402 million, the largest sum spent by the Board in any one year since its inception in 1963. A further $438 million will be spent in 1978.

    In the first seven months of this year maximum demand for electricity reached

960    Mw (mega watts) - an increase of 10% over the maximum demand of 872 Mw last year. Average daily consumption of water was 629,000 cubic metres in the first seven months of 1977, increasing to 668,000 cubic metres in the first seven months of 1978, representing a 6.21% increase. The average daily production of gas in the first seven months of the year was 1.42 million units, an increase of 8.69% over the production for the same period last year.

    Despite larger capital expenditure and the rising cost of labour, materials and equipment, fuel oil, and naphtha, the Board has been able to keep tariffs for electricity and gas unchanged for the past four and a half years. This has been made possible by the more efficient use of machines and manpower. There is however a limit to the

Column: 48

Board's ability to absorb further oil price increases. Tariff revisions will aim at making consumers economise by conserving electricity, water and gas.

    From July this year the Board has been supplying electricity to Johore Bahru to help meet the demand for electricity there. This Singapore- Malaysia electrical network link is a step towards the ultimate achievement of a pan-ASEAN electricity grid system. Power system interconnections are beneficial because they make possible the pooling of resources, with a consequent reduction in capital and operating costs.

DEVELOPMENT FOR THE NEXT FOUR YEARS

Electricity

    Much of Stage II of the $597.6 million Senoko Power Station will be completed by the end of 1979. This development, comprising three 250 Mw units, will bring the generating capacity of the Station to 1110 Mw.

    The older, less efficient units at Pasir Panjang 'A' Power Station and the old gas turbines at St James Power Station will be run down when Senoko's three 250 Mw units are in operation in the latter half of 1980.

    Construction of Stage III of Senoko Power Station comprising two 250 Mw units will commence in 1980 and be completed by 1984. This final extension of Senoko Power Station will bring its total capacity to 1610 Mw.

Water

    The Pulau Tekong Water Scheme (estimated cost: $7.3 million) is expected to be completed in mid-1979. Piped water supplies will then be available.

    The $69 million Western Catchments Scheme will be completed in 1981, increasing Singapore's reservoir storage capacity by 28.4 million cubic metres.

    During this period, work will commence on another two reservoirs - the Sungei

Column: 49

Seletar estuary reservoir and the Bedok reservoir - to increase the Republic's reservoir capacity by 18 million cubic metres. Both these schemes are estimated to cost over $100 million.

    Water reclamation by advanced wastewater treatment processes to increase the Republic's sources of supplies is also being studied jointly with the Ministry of the Environment.

Gas

    A new gas reformer will be required by 1980 to cater for gas demand in the early 1980s. The new gas plant will have a capacity of 0.776 million units per day and is expected to cost $3.5 million. The five heavy fuel oil plants at the Gasworks will be scrapped and only the more efficient pollution-free naphtha reformers will be used.

MINISTRY OF NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT


    The Ministry of National Development plays a key role in the physical development of Singapore. It aims at maximising land use through careful planning, laying the infra-structure for a thriving metropolis and building a pleasant environment for healthy and gracious living.

    The major task facing the Ministry is the planning and rebuilding of the Central Area to bring back residential population of all income groups. Both public housing and private residential housing will be encouraged. Sites will be released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority to the private sector for development. Planning requirements and URA's sales conditions will ensure development of a high standard and quality.

    The URA will continue to acquire and clear slums in the Central Area for development. In particular, it will accelerate urban

Column: 50

development along the corridor from Tanglin Circus through Orchard Road, Bras Basah Road and Raffles International Centre into Marina Centre. One hundred hectares of reclaimed land at Marina Centre are now ready for the development of hotels, shopping complexes and entertainment/ recreational facilities.

    The Ministry will continue to improve the urban landscape to give the city a cool, green and pleasant environment. There will be more open spaces, pedestrian malls and landscaped walkways. In the Central Area, the Public Works Department is building a network of walkways and pedestrian malls to link the various commercial centres and offices. 12,000 of a proposed 34,000 metres of walkways have been laid. There will also be more overhead bridges, underpasses and bus shelters for pedestrians. All these will be graced with trees and flowering shrubs by the Parks and Recreation Department. In addition, the Department will develop six more major parks covering 270 hectares in all. Another step to spruce up the city is to acquire and demolish dilapidated structures along the major highways. The acquisition and clearance for economic use of land on which squatters are living and cemeteries will continue.

Housing and Public Works

    Having housed 60% of the population, the Housing and Development Board will now concentrate on improving the design and quality of flats to be built: proposals include larger floor areas, higher ceilings, more lifts and better finish. The HDB will introduce more imaginative layouts for new estates and greater variety in building designs. In the old estates, the HDB will build recreational and social facilities like swimming pools, and install more and better lifts. The older blocks of flats will be refurbished into larger flat units or demolished.

    By 1980, about 70% of the population will live in HDB flats. A pilot scheme of Residents' Committees has been started in five areas to generate better neighbourhood ties and community spirit. When the form of

Column: 51

the organisation has been settled successfully, Residents' Committees will be formed in other housing estates.

    The PWD is presently engaged in several major road construction projects, such as the East Coast Parkway and the Pan Island Expressway. Projects scheduled for 1979 include the flyover at Newton Circus, the extension of the Bukit Timah One-Way System to link up with the East Coast Parkway, the Cross Street/Pickering Street One-Way System, the West Coast Arterial Road, and the Commonwealth Avenue Extension to Jurong.

    Other major projects undertaken by the Ministry are the Changi Airport Development, the construction of the University of Singapore Campus at Kent Ridge and the development of Kent Ridge Hospital.

Primary Production

    Pork, eggs and poultry production will have to increase through better farm management in order to stay economic in land-scarce Singapore. New farming methods such as hydroponics are under experiment.

    A centralised wholesale market for fruits and vegetables will be built at Pasir Panjang. A second fishing port and wholesale market is planned for Punggol to replace the out-dated facilities at Kangkar.

Column: 52



Resettlement

    Delays in resettlement are a major constraint in the implementation of public projects. In the years ahead, the tempo of resettlement will quicken. URA and HDB will therefore build adequate resettlement centres, some of which will be for special trades. Resettlement facilities will also be provided for industries which cause pollution.

Reclamation

    About 300 hectares have been reclaimed next to the Central Business District. Reclamation work on another 360 hectares has begun. When completed, there will be a total of 660 hectares of land available for building on.

    About 44 hectares of land will be reclaimed off Pasir Ris Beach for development into a major park to serve the recreational needs in the north-eastern sector of Singapore.

    To protect Singapore's water resources, pig farming will continue to be phased out from all Water Catchment Areas. The farmers will be resettled on land reclaimed from swamps in Sungei Buloh, Lim Chu Kang. Reclamation of the foreshore areas at Pulau Tekong for farming purposes is also being considered.
LIM KIM SAN
Minister for National Development
